title: How many seats in the National Assembly will the Fidesz party's list win in the next Hungarian parliamentary election?
possible_answers: A two-thirds supermajority (133 seats or more)
A majority but not a two-thirds supermajority (between 100 seats and 132 seats)
Less than a majority (fewer than 100 seats)
correct_answer: A two-thirds supermajority (133 seats or more)
preds:
"The election arithmetic suggests a closer race than the government would like. According to opposition paper Nepszava, Fidesz is assured of victory in 41 of the country's 106 individual constituencies, while the opposition alliance can count on 33. That leaves 32 battleground districts where the opposition has to break through. The remaining 93 seats in Hungary's 199 seat Parliament are divided according to party lists. Different polling agencies suggest a record turnout - perhaps as high as 80%, compared with 70% four years ago. In a country of 9.7 million, the electorate was split almost evenly - 2.6 million apiece - four years ago. Pollsters reckon that this election will be decided by between 300,000 and 600,000 voters who are either undecided or uncommitted, and who are in the cross-hairs of campaigners from both sides."
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-60952882 EDIT:
https://www.economist.com/graphic-detail/2022/04/02/a-wild-gerrymander-makes-hungarys-fidesz-party-hard-to-dislodge

"Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban doubled his poll lead a little more than a month before a general election, according to a survey taken just as Russia started its invasion of Ukraine. Orban’s Fidesz party had the support of 50% of decided voters compared with 40% for an alliance of six opposition parties, pollster Median said on the HVG news website on Wednesday. The poll was taken between Feb. 22 and 26. Median’s survey in December showed Fidesz with a 5-point lead."
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-03-02/orban-s-party-widens-hungary-poll-lead-as-russia-invades-ukraine However, over the past 12 years of Orban's uninterrupted empery the Hungarian Forint lost almost 36% in value against the EUR, 13% alone year-to-date.
The Economy, Orban.
I expect Hungarians to be increasingly disgusted by Putin-style Borschtsch-totalitarianism and its Fidesz counterfeit and are going to try to avoid ambiguity and uncertainty.

Adjusting forecast based on an apparent decrease in opposition polling numbers over the past month. Fidesz seems to have gained a little bit more of an advantage. Slowly but surely time is running out for major upheavals between now and the election. https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/hungary/
Adjusting up as the coalition is holding together for now!

I don't know this situation at all, but it seems from the polling that Fidesz and United for Hungary are close in the polls, making a supermajority very unlikely. Still a slight advantage to Fidesz-KNDP, because of incumbency, plus the possibility Orban being able to use certain non-democratic means to influence the vote.

I hadn’t previously appreciated the extent of re-districting in favor of Fidesz. 
I’m also seeing a bit more negative sentiment by commentators regarding the “Rube Goldberg machine”-nature of the opposition, and the need for many moving parts to work together perfectly. There seems to have been more optimism that it could work a month or more back. https://amp.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/02/outsider-peter-marki-zay-from-the-right-backed-by-hungarys-left-to-beat-orban https://hungarytoday.hu/press-roundup-fidesz-government-opposition-analyst-elections-violence-2022/

- There are 199 seats in the assembly. Per above, a majority is 100 seats, and a supermajority is 132 or more.
- Fidesz has 133 seats currently.
- In order to lose its supermajority, Fidesz will have to lose 2 seats.
- In order to lose its majority, Fidesz will have to lose 34 seats. Orban has been in government for a long time, e.g. since 1990. Fidesz has had a majority since 2010, and during that whole time (three elections) it has had a supermajority. Hungary got a new constitution in 2014 and I don't consider previous elections precisely comparable. So for simplicity's sake I will use the 2018 and 2014 elections as reference classes. Relative to the individual other parties, early polling doesn't look that different than it did in those cases (that is, no single party or set of parties is performing meaningfully better than in the past), so the instrumental scenario that would lead to a situation other than the status quo in this case is the idea that the opposition will in fact be unified. Back to that in a moment. It's definitely possible that Fidesz will lose those two seats- but I don't know how possible it really is. It's true Fidesz is polling a bit lower than it did at this point in the past, but I really don't know how much to update on that. I think the fact that the party has maintained a narrow supermajority for three elections, and an identical seat count for two, should be informative.  So I'll plant a flag here indicating the following vague ideas
- The fact that Fidesz has maintained narrow electoral supremacy for three elections should count for something. I think more than 10%- maybe between 20% and 25%.
- A lot of things need to happen for Orban to lose his supermajority, but I don't think those things are crazy.

"A generation of right-wing populists [] have risen to power in democracies like Turkey [] have coincided, at least at first, with periods of solid economic performance[]. They have remained in power by stoking nationalist passions and driving deep wedges into the electorate with hot-button cultural issues. Along the way, they have co-opted the news media and cowed opponents. Now these strongmen are grappling with rising prices, even as they face national elections within the next two years. In Hungary, where consumer prices are rising at their fastest pace since 2007, polls suggest that Mr. Orban will face his toughest election ever next year, as the cost of living and low wages become top concerns for voters.
Voters in the nearby Czech Republic — which has faced rising inflation and soaring energy costs — just ousted Andrej Babis, the country’s billionaire right-wing populist prime minister, by a narrow margin.
“Since the global financial recession, the global macroeconomic environment was a godsend to authoritarians,” said Daron Acemoglu, a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who has studied the deterioration of democracies. “Essentially, with very low interest rates, it made many countries that had either weak democracies or semi-authoritarianism, or sometimes fully fledged authoritarianism, still attractive to foreign capital.”
Their personalized approach to politics — and the fact that they have all been in office for years — makes it difficult for them to sidestep blame for the condition of the economy. At the same time, their brand of populism, which emphasizes nationalist rivalries and has been effective in the past, can seem out of touch to citizens whose standards of living are swiftly plummeting. Most observers think Mr. Erdogan has made a difficult situation much worse, with the prospect of more interest rate cuts and currency declines driving foreign investors to pull their money from Turkey.
https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/13/business/inflation-turkey-brazil-hungary.html Poll of Polls (https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/hungary/) has Fidesz and the opposition almost neck and neck, which would make the disproportionate super-majority less likely. I'll shift my forecast toward it being a much tighter race.
overplayed their hands in biting the hand that feeds Hungary. the people will realize and act in line
There will likely be large scale rigging and tilting of levers however it will be difficult to keep a two thirds majority

To get a supermajority, Orban needs to equal or outperform last election.  Given (a) a united opposition and (b) new surge in covid amongst a not-very-vaccinated population (c) various economic issues (see linked article) and (d) polling, I think that option is very unlikely.  I also don't think Hungary is quite at the stage where Orban could easily just write his own result (Freedom House has Hungary as "partly free" currently). Whether he gets a majority or not is harder.  Reading just polls and EU-focused news would suggest United Opposition have a slight edge.  But Orban has a lot of 'infrastructure' he can bring to bear, particularly if it looks like he's losing.  So I think he's still the favourite. But I don't think his state control makes him a certain winner; see Poland's PiS losing the Senate in 2019, and Moldova (with a worse Freedom House score than Hungary) successfully replaced their president with a liberal pro-EU candidate. https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/hungary-opposition-makes-gains-raising-stakes-orban-poll-2021-11-17/
The polls look similar enough to the 2018 election that it would be surprising if Fidesz didn't win a new majority.
Pro-European sentiments will prevail but propaganda will be lucrative.
After Merkel and Kurtz next one for dismantling is Orban

The probability of Fidesz losing its majority seems higher now than ever before since Orban came to power (double-digit percentages!). The opposition and Fidesz are widely reported to be neck-in-neck in recent polling. Still, Orban has a lot of possibilities to make elections less than completely “free and fair”, so I’m assessing far less than even odds that the opposition will prevail.  https://www.thenewfederalist.eu/can-the-hungarian-opposition-win-in-2022?lang=fr https://euobserver.com/democracy/153499 https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/budapest-hosts-rival-political-rallies-hungarys-2022-election-race-heats-up-2021-10-23/

Probably still too early to tell how crooked Orban's thugs are willing to be.  In what used to be called a free and fair election they'd get a majority but not a super-majority; stay tuned. Sometimes it is hard to remember that Fidesz used to be the reasonable and sensible centre-right party, rather like the US Republicans once were  (insert audible sigh here).

"The Czech vote will be disquieting news for the Hungarian leader Viktor Orban, the self-declared standard-bearer of “illiberal democracy,” whose Fidesz party faces elections next year and could well lose if its fractious opponents stick to pledges to form a united front. [] The results, while far from a decisive victory for the opposition, delivered an unexpected rebuke to Mr. Babis, a tycoon who has dominated the Czech political scene for nearly a decade" https://www.nytimes.com/2021/10/09/world/europe/andrej-babis-defeated-czech-republic.html "Having failed to unseat prime minister Viktor Orbán since he came to power in 2010, six opposition parties plan to unite behind joint candidates, both in parliamentary constituencies and for the post of premier, a tactic unprecedented in modern Hungarian history. [] The opposition were buoyed by a surprise win in the 2019 Budapest mayoral election, which saw a candidate chosen by a similar primary process prevail against his Fidesz opponent" 
"The opposition parties hope to be able to counteract the effects of Hungary’s majoritarian electoral system, which gives a huge boost – more seats than their share of the vote – to the winning party. Orbán’s ruling Fidesz party won the last election on 49 per cent of the vote but gained two thirds of seats."
https://www.newstatesman.com/world/europe/2021/10/why-hungarys-opposition-parties-are-uniting-against-viktor-orban "Conservative politician Péter Márki-Zay has won the race to become the Hungarian opposition’s joint candidate for prime minister, as anti-Orbán parties unite in an effort to oust the sitting premier. [] Márki-Zay, who is not affiliated with a political party, received nearly 57 percent of the vote. [] The race against Márki-Zay will be the first time Orbán, who first assumed power in 2010, will face a united group of opposition parties vying to oust him from his post." https://thehill.com/policy/international/577133-conservative-wins-hungary-opposition-race-as-anti-orban-parties-unite It seems like the political tides are turning, but as always the vote will be more determined by economic conditions than anything. "in mid-September the government and social partners reached an agreement to hike the minimum wage by almost 20% in 2022, with small- and medium-sized businesses to receive tax relief in exchange. Moreover, the government announced it will refund USD 2 billion of income tax to families in early 2022, while it also eased repayment rules for some loans under an extended debt moratorium. Meanwhile, in late September Moody's raised Hungary's rating to “Baa2” from “Baa3”, citing the country’s strong growth rebound and outlook." https://www.focus-economics.com/countries/hungary So, the economy is looking good, the rules favour Orban, and the opposition is attempting to unite a very broad front, which is also likely to alienate some voters. I'd say he's likely to retain power but they may make enough strides to keep him below a supermajority. That said, it's still a way off and China's issues could become global issues before the election and change voter opinions if the economy falters. We'll also have to see how strong and cohesive the opposition message comes across as the campaign develops.
